Explaining Required Darwin Core Terms In the Context of Data#

Those of you reading this have probably guessed that “Required Terms” are terms that you need to include in your data. But what do they actually mean when they are in a dataset?

Take the following example (visualised using the Python library pandas - example data here)

                           occurrenceID        scientificName  decimalLatitude  decimalLongitude   eventDate          vernacularName taxonRank               species       genus      family      order          class      phylum  kingdom  coordinateUncertaintyInMeters geodeticDatum     basisOfRecord
0  914ced9b-d860-4373-aa71-5d3356f442f0    Corymbia latifolia           -13.04            131.07  2022-03-29  Round-leaved Bloodwood   species    Corymbia latifolia    Corymbia   Myrtaceae   Myrtales  Equisetopsida  Charophyta  Plantae                            100         WGS84  HumanObservation
1  d3dd23c6-43f7-428b-93b4-1e0f5807aea3  Eucalyptus tectifica           -13.04            131.07  2022-09-13                Grey Box   species  Eucalyptus tectifica  Eucalyptus   Myrtaceae   Myrtales  Equisetopsida  Charophyta  Plantae                            100         WGS84  HumanObservation
2  572ecb59-b2e1-4926-859b-f0f617c6a5fe        Banksia aemula           -33.60            150.72  2022-08-15                Banyalla   species        Banksia aemula     Banksia  Proteaceae  Proteales  Equisetopsida  Charophyta  Plantae                            100         WGS84  HumanObservation
3  2d3240cf-390e-4a05-b623-da1ff0d697d4   Eucalyptus racemosa           -33.60            150.72  2022-06-16            Scribbly Gum   species   Eucalyptus racemosa  Eucalyptus   Myrtaceae   Myrtales  Equisetopsida  Charophyta  Plantae                            100         WGS84  HumanObservation
4  5b4ecdcd-271d-4bc7-ba1e-74022d1a8ab3     Persoonia laurina           -33.60            150.72  2022-10-19                     NaN   species     Persoonia laurina   Persoonia  Proteaceae  Proteales  Equisetopsida  Charophyta  Plantae                            100         WGS84  HumanObservation

If you scroll to the right, you can see that there are a lot of columns, but why are there so many? And why are there so many that are required?

How is an occurrence recorded? (basisOfRecord)#

Let’s now look at the column titled basisOfRecord (in the dataset visualised above, it is the column all the way to the right.)

0    HumanObservation
1    HumanObservation
2    HumanObservation
3    HumanObservation
4    HumanObservation
Name: basisOfRecord, dtype: object

The term basisOfRecord is not an obvious one, but it is required for all data that fits within the Darwin Core Standard. It is a description of how someone recorded their observation. For those of you who read the Introduction To The Available Standards, under “Darwin Core” it mentions you can specify whether the observation is via a human spotting it, if it’s a museum specimen, a sample, etc. For this example dataset, it is set to HumanObservation. Other terms include PreservedSpecimen and MaterialSample. For a full list of possible values go to the Vocabulary List and look under the “Darwin Core” tab. basisOfRecord will be under the Required section, and will include examples.

When is an occurrence recorded? (eventDate)#

Now that we know how the observation was recorded, when was it recorded? This is specified by the eventDate column.

0    2022-03-29
1    2022-09-13
2    2022-08-15
3    2022-06-16
4    2022-10-19
Name: eventDate, dtype: object

The eventDate is relatively self-explanatory, where it refers to the date on which the occurrence occurred. This is usually in the format YYYY-MM-DD, or YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS where the T splits the date and the time. Including the time can be particularly useful for species that are noctural.

Where is an occurrence recorded? (Spatial Information)#

Knowing where an occurrence was recorded follows describing how and when it was recorded. However, there are a few extra pieces of information you need to included to make your data richer and more meaningful:

   decimalLatitude  decimalLongitude geodeticDatum  coordinateUncertaintyInMeters
0           -13.04            131.07         WGS84                            100
1           -13.04            131.07         WGS84                            100
2           -33.60            150.72         WGS84                            100
3           -33.60            150.72         WGS84                            100
4           -33.60            150.72         WGS84                            100

decimalLatitude and decimlLongitude are pretty self-explanatory, in that they represent degrees latitude and degrees longitude of where the species was recorded. Along with this is something called coordinateUncertaintyInMeters. This is the error on your latitude and longitude measurement. For example, if you are recording a sighting using the GPS on your phone, this has an inherent measurement uncertainty. The error that is most common, or most likely, is 100 meters, which is why that is the value in this dataset.

geodeticDatum is a term that describes a Coordinate Reference System (CRS). A CRS is a specific way to represent data from a 3D spherical object (in this case, planet Earth) onto a two-dimensional surface. As you can imagine, there are many ways to do this, and knowing which way you are representing these points prevents confusion between two datsets, as knowing the CRS could explain potential discrepancies in the data. The Atlas of Living Australia uses the World Geodetic System 84, or WGS84, as shown in the dataset. This standard is used in satellite navigation and GPS.

What species was recorded? (Taxonomic Information)#

Now that we’ve answered the “When” and “Where”, we will answer the “What”. Specifically, what species was observed?

The ALA requires the following information from users, shown below in the example dataset:

  • scientificName

  • taxonRank

  • kingdom

  • phylum

  • class

  • order

  • family

  • genus

         scientificName taxonRank  kingdom      phylum          class      order      family       genus
0    Corymbia latifolia   species  Plantae  Charophyta  Equisetopsida   Myrtales   Myrtaceae    Corymbia
1  Eucalyptus tectifica   species  Plantae  Charophyta  Equisetopsida   Myrtales   Myrtaceae  Eucalyptus
2        Banksia aemula   species  Plantae  Charophyta  Equisetopsida  Proteales  Proteaceae     Banksia
3   Eucalyptus racemosa   species  Plantae  Charophyta  Equisetopsida   Myrtales   Myrtaceae  Eucalyptus
4     Persoonia laurina   species  Plantae  Charophyta  Equisetopsida  Proteales  Proteaceae   Persoonia

This is to ensure that the species you have seen has been correctly identified according to the taxonomic backbone you are using. Here, we are using the ALA backbone. This will also help disambiguate things like homonyms, or other identification mistakes and errors. Adding higher order taxa is straightforward with the galaxias-python package, though it is always a good idea to double-check your taxonomy before submitting data. If you are concerned about any taxonomy suggestions/recommendations the ALA has made for your species, please email contact us.

How Can I Make Every Observation Unique? (Unique Identifiers)#

The final requirement for every observation is a way to make your observation unique, especially in a large data repository. The easiest way to do this is to generate a Globally Unique Identifier (GUID) or a Universally Unique Identifier (UUID). There are ways to do this in Python or galaxias-python, but they should look like this:

                           occurrenceID
0  914ced9b-d860-4373-aa71-5d3356f442f0
1  d3dd23c6-43f7-428b-93b4-1e0f5807aea3
2  572ecb59-b2e1-4926-859b-f0f617c6a5fe
3  2d3240cf-390e-4a05-b623-da1ff0d697d4
4  5b4ecdcd-271d-4bc7-ba1e-74022d1a8ab3
